speaker: sam
text: Welcome back to Tech Leadership Unpacked. I'm Sam Rivera. We're in the home stretch - episode nine. Today we're talking about API design, and I'll admit, this might seem deeply technical, but APIs are increasingly a product concern.

speaker: alex
text: I'm Alex Chen. Sam's right. If you have external developers, partners, or even internal teams consuming your services, your API is a product. A well-designed API creates leverage - people can build on your platform. A poorly designed API creates friction, support burden, and abandoned integrations.

speaker: sam
text: So how do we build APIs that developers love?

speaker: alex
text: That's exactly what we'll cover. We'll talk principles that apply whether you're building REST, GraphQL, or internal services.

speaker: sam
text: Let's start with principles. What makes a good API?

speaker: alex
text: Several qualities matter.

speaker: sam
text: That seems obvious. Why does it go wrong?

speaker: alex
text: Different teams building different endpoints. No style guide. Rushing to ship. You end up with /users returning {users: []} and /products returning {items: []}. Small inconsistencies multiply into confusion.

speaker: alex
text: Intuitiveness - developers can guess how things work. If you know how to list users, you can guess how to list products. Following conventions and patterns makes APIs learnable.

speaker: sam
text: What conventions matter?

speaker: alex
text: Industry standards like REST conventions, HTTP verb semantics, status codes. If your API uses POST for everything and returns 200 for errors, you're fighting expectations.

speaker: alex
text: Simplicity - the API does what's needed without unnecessary complexity. Every optional parameter, every configuration flag, every edge case you support has a maintenance cost. Start simple, add complexity only when needed.

speaker: sam
text: Isn't more flexibility better?

speaker: alex
text: Flexibility has costs. More ways to do things means more ways to do things wrong, more documentation needed, more support questions. Opinionated APIs that guide users toward the right path are often better.

speaker: alex
text: Evolvability - the API can change without breaking existing users. You'll always need to add features, fix mistakes, evolve the product. Good API design anticipates change.

speaker: sam
text: How do you design for change?

speaker: alex
text: Versioning strategies, additive-only changes, deprecation policies. We'll dig into these.

speaker: alex
text: Documentation - this isn't really a property of the API itself, but it's inseparable. An undocumented API barely exists. Documentation is part of the product.

speaker: sam
text: REST is still the most common API style, right? Let's go deep there.

speaker: alex

speaker: alex
text: That's an anti-pattern. Status codes exist for a reason. Clients and infrastructure (caches, load balancers, monitoring) rely on them. If you return 200 for errors, retries won't work correctly, caching breaks, and clients can't trust responses.

text: How do you handle API changes over time?

speaker: alex
text: This is one of the hardest parts of API design. Once an API is in use, changing it is painful.

speaker: sam
text: What counts as a breaking change?

speaker: alex
text: Removing or renaming fields. Changing field types. Changing required/optional status. Changing response structure. Removing endpoints. Changing error formats.

speaker: sam
text: How do you handle breaking changes when you need them?

speaker: alex
text: Versioning. Common strategies:

speaker: sam
text: Which do you prefer?

speaker: alex
text: URL versioning for clarity, especially for public APIs. Internal APIs can use headers or content negotiation.

speaker: alex
text: Deprecation policies are critical. When you version:

speaker: sam
text: How long should you support old versions?

speaker: alex
text: Depends on your users. Internal APIs can move faster. Public APIs with enterprise customers might need years. Set expectations upfront and stick to them.

speaker: alex
text: Compatibility strategies:

speaker: sam
text: What about field defaults?

speaker: alex
text: Tricky area. If you add a required field to a creation request, that's breaking. Solutions: make new fields optional with defaults, or gate behind feature flags or versions.

speaker: sam
text: We have a whole episode on security, but let's touch on API-specific concerns.

speaker: alex
text: Key considerations:

speaker: sam
text: Which should we use?

speaker: alex
text: API keys for simple integrations, especially internal. OAuth for user authorization, especially if third parties access user data. JWTs often paired with OAuth as the token format.

speaker: alex
text: Authorization - who can do what:

speaker: alex
text: Rate limiting - prevent abuse:

speaker: alex
text: HTTPS everywhere. No exceptions. API keys and tokens over HTTP are exposed. HSTS headers to enforce.

speaker: sam
text: What about input validation?

speaker: alex
text: Validate everything. Type checking, length limits, allowed values. Return clear validation errors. Never trust client input. This prevents security issues and improves developer experience.

speaker: sam
text: Let's talk about documentation. You said it's part of the product.

speaker: alex
text: Maybe the most important part for external APIs. Good docs = adoption. Bad docs = support tickets.

speaker: sam
text: What tools are standard?

speaker: alex
text: OpenAPI (Swagger) - spec for describing REST APIs. Tools generate docs, SDKs, mocks from the spec.

speaker: sam
text: Should we generate SDKs?

speaker: alex
text: For major platforms - JavaScript, Python, Ruby, Go - SDKs dramatically improve developer experience. Generated from OpenAPI or hand-crafted for polish.

speaker: alex
text: Interactive documentation is powerful. Try-it-out features in docs let developers experiment without writing code. Reduces time to first successful call.

speaker: sam
text: What makes documentation great?

speaker: alex
text: Clear, concise writing. Realistic examples. Good search. Up-to-date with the actual API. Version-matched. Quick path to solving real problems.

speaker: alex
text: Developer experience (DX) goes beyond docs:

speaker: sam
text: Let's summarize. What should product leaders know about API design?

speaker: alex
text: APIs are products. They have users, they need design, they need documentation, they need support. Treat them with the same rigor as your customer-facing product.

speaker: sam
text: Who should own API design?

speaker: alex
text: Joint ownership between product (what capabilities to expose) and engineering (how to expose them well). For public APIs, consider a dedicated API product manager.

speaker: alex
text: Consistency over perfection. A consistent API is better than a perfect one. Establish patterns early, document them, enforce them in code review.

speaker: alex
text: Plan for evolution. You will make mistakes. You will need to add features. Design for change with versioning, deprecation policies, and additive changes.

speaker: alex
text: Invest in developer experience. Time spent on docs, SDKs, and examples pays back in adoption, reduced support, and developer goodwill.

speaker: sam
text: Any anti-patterns to avoid?

speaker: alex
text: Exposing internal implementation. Your API should model the domain, not your database schema.

speaker: sam
text: One thing to remember?

speaker: alex
text: Think of your API from the consumer's perspective. Every design decision should make their life easier. If you wouldn't want to use your own API, redesign it.
